caption: Figure 1: Analysis on spike frequency variation of GCN using IMDB-BINARY [54] dataset.
description: The figure shows the analysis of spike frequency variation in Graph Convolutional Networks (GCNs) using the IMDB-BINARY dataset. It consists of two subfigures: (a) Histogram showing the distribution of total spikes counted over time for each node, demonstrating that many nodes show very few spikes, suggesting the problem of neuron starvation, and (b) Heatmap visualizing spike frequency across layers and nodes grouped and sorted by node degree. The heatmap reveals patterns such as high-degree nodes exhibiting higher spike frequencies, spike frequencies correlated with the corresponding nodes, and feature neurons within a node behaving differently according to their positions.

caption: Figure 1: Analysis on spike frequency variation of GCN using IMDB-BINARY [54] dataset.
description: This figure analyzes the spike frequency variation in Graph Convolutional Networks (GCNs) using the IMDB-BINARY dataset.  Subfigure (a) shows histograms of the total spike counts for each node across three layers of the GCN, revealing a skewed distribution with many nodes having few spikes (starvation). Subfigure (b) presents a heatmap visualizing spike frequency across feature dimensions and nodes sorted by degree. Brighter colors indicate higher spike frequencies. This heatmap demonstrates that high-degree nodes tend to exhibit higher spike frequencies, illustrating the correlation between node degree and spike frequency.  The horizontal strips represent the spike frequencies associated with specific nodes, while vertical strips show differing behavior of feature neurons within a single node.

caption: Figure 2: Overall graph classification architecture with proposed methods.
description: This figure illustrates the overall architecture of the TAS-GNN model for graph classification.  The input graphs are first encoded into spike representations using a Poisson encoder. Then, the message passing is performed in a spike format within multiple GNN layers interspersed with SNN layers that include the proposed topology-aware group-adaptive neurons. Finally, the graph embeddings are processed by a readout layer and a classification head to produce the classification result. This process is repeated for multiple timesteps (t=1 to t=T) to further refine the classification decision.

caption: Figure 3: Sensitivity of neurons to its initial threshold.
description: This figure shows the sensitivity of the adaptive neurons in the proposed TAS-GNN model to their initial threshold values. The accuracy of the model is plotted against different initial threshold values (Vinit) for three different GNN architectures: GCN, GAT, and GIN. The results demonstrate that the performance of the adaptive neurons is highly sensitive to the choice of initial threshold values, indicating the need for careful tuning or learning of these values.

caption: Figure 4: Sensitivity study of neurons to its initial threshold.
description: This figure shows the sensitivity analysis of neurons to their initial thresholds. The x-axis represents different initial threshold values, and the y-axis represents the accuracy. Three different GNN models (GCN, GAT, and GIN) are compared in terms of their performance under both the topology-aware group adaptive neuron (TAG) method and the proposed method. The results indicate that the proposed method is less sensitive to initial threshold variations, demonstrating its robustness and stability.

caption: Figure 6: Histogram plotting distribution of total spikes counted over time for each node. X-axis denotes spike counts from each node, while y-axis denotes density of each bin.
description: This figure shows the distribution of total spikes counted over time for each node in different datasets and models. The X-axis represents the number of spikes per node, while the Y-axis represents the density of nodes with that number of spikes. The figure is split into subplots, each showing the distribution for a different dataset (MUTAG, PROTEINS, ENZYMES, NCI1, IMDB-BINARY) and model (SpikingGNN and TAS-GNN). The figure aims to illustrate the impact of TAS-GNN in alleviating the neuron starvation problem by showing a more uniform spike distribution across nodes, indicating that the modified model utilizes more neurons effectively.
